item.title: Coolest sport ever
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

You’re supposed to spread costs over at least a year. Sure, you pay $3000, but you don’t use it once.

Read full topic

item.title: Coolest sport ever
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I’m casually employed, as mentioned in my post. If I had part time or full time employment then I would indeed have sick leave, holiday leave, compassionate leave, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Coolest sport ever
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:22, topic:374051”][quote author=Rix_ link=topic=470033.msg3439316#msg3439316 date=1292981207]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=470033.msg3438577#msg3438577 date=1292953363]How is it super expensive? Most sports cost that much.
[/quote]
Well, a complete wingsuit would cost at least $1700 and that it without a course (a private course costs $1000). Expensive for me, I guess.
[/quote]
It depends on how you view something like this. I earn $20, as I’m a casual employee – that is to say that they pay me more per hour worked, but I don’t get sick leave/holiday leave/etc.
A $3000 startup cost is 150 hours of work. I average about 15 hours a week, so I’m looking at 10 weeks work.

In short, it’s expensive to buy into the sport but the ongoing costs are low. There are cheaper sports, but most sports require at least a couple of hundred dollars initial expenditure (ie, a tennis racket and bag for tennis, or a set of golf clubs). Higher end equipment is obviously more expensive, with some tennis rackets easily costing $500+. Whatever.

But yeah, if you were to take it seriously and actually take part in the sport regularly, it becomes a lot cheaper in the long-run.[/quote]No sick leave or holiday? What the fuck? Your country is fucked up. It is set in stone by law here.

Read full topic

item.title: Coolest sport ever
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Rix_, post:19, topic:374051”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=470033.msg3438577#msg3438577 date=1292953363]How is it super expensive? Most sports cost that much.
[/quote]
Well, a complete wingsuit would cost at least $1700 and that it without a course (a private course costs $1000). Expensive for me, I guess. ;)[/quote]
It depends on how you view something like this. I earn $20, as I’m a casual employee – that is to say that they pay me more per hour worked, but I don’t get sick leave/holiday leave/etc.
A $3000 startup cost is 150 hours of work. I average about 15 hours a week, so I’m looking at 10 weeks work.

In short, it’s expensive to buy into the sport but the ongoing costs are low. There are cheaper sports, but most sports require at least a couple of hundred dollars initial expenditure (ie, a tennis racket and bag for tennis, or a set of golf clubs). Higher end equipment is obviously more expensive, with some tennis rackets easily costing $500+. Whatever.

But yeah, if you were to take it seriously and actually take part in the sport regularly, it becomes a lot cheaper in the long-run.

Read full topic

item.title: Coolest sport ever
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“maniown, post:11, topic:374051”]I wonder if it would be possible to do with snowboarding… I used to ski when I was younger, but I snowboard now.

We’re talking a 2000$ parachute and a 600$ pair of skis to do this. Rich mans sport.[/quote]
On the contrary, I’d say that $2000 isn’t that expensive if you want to do it badly enough. Just look at sports like go kart racing, where the buy in is in excess of $3000 for a decent kart, and then ongoing expenses like the tyres and fuel.
As long as you don’t spend the $2000 and then manage to cut the parachute to shreds.

Read full topic
